senses.definition: a piece of furniture that consists of a flat top supported by legs

examples.en: We sat at a round table in the corner.

to lay the table (= to put the plates, knives, etc. on it for a meal)

a pool/billiard/snooker table

senses.definition: the people sitting at a table for a meal or to play cards, etc.

examples.en: He kept the whole table entertained with his jokes.

senses.definition: a list of facts or numbers arranged in a special order, usually in rows and columns

variants.html: (also multiplication table, informal times table)

senses.definition: to contribute something useful to a discussion, project, etc.

senses.definition: to join formal discussions about something

senses.definition: to drink more alcohol than somebody else without becoming as drunk as they are

idioms.word: lay/put your cards on the table

senses.definition: to tell somebody honestly what your plans, ideas, etc. are

senses.definition: offered to people so that they can consider or discuss it

senses.definition: not going to be discussed or considered until a future date
to change a situation so that you are now in a stronger position than the person who used to be in a stronger position than you
to serve food to people, for example at a formal meal
to work serving food to people in a restaurant
to present something formally for discussion

senses.definition: to leave an idea, a proposal, etc. to be discussed at a later date

variants.html: (also Tablet PC™)

senses.definition: a small computer that is easy to carry, with a large touch screen and usually without a physical keyboard

examples.en: The company has launched its latest 10-inch tablet.

senses.definition: a small round solid piece of medicine that you swallow

senses.definition: an amount of a substance in a small, round, solid piece

senses.definition: a piece of soap
a number of pieces of paper for writing or drawing on, that are fastened together at one edge

senses.definition: a man’s sexual organs
the particular method you use to achieve something

variants.html: tactics

connected with the particular method you use to achieve something

examples.en: tactical planning

senses.definition: carefully planned in order to achieve a particular aim

examples.en: a tactical decision

senses.definition: used or having an effect over short distances or for a short time

examples.en: tactical weapons/missiles
tactical nuclear weapons

senses.definition: connected with military tactics

senses.definition: a small piece of paper, cloth, plastic, etc. attached to something to identify it or give information about it

variants.html: (British English also tig)

a symbol or name used by a graffiti writer and painted in a public place

senses.definition: to give somebody/something a name that describes what they are or do

senses.definition: to leave a name or mark on a piece of graffiti to show who made it

senses.definition: having the type of tail mentioned

senses.definition: the back part of a plane, spacecraft, etc.

senses.definition: a part of something that sticks out at the back like a tail

senses.definition: the last part of something that is moving away from you

variants.html: tails

senses.definition: a long jacket divided at the back below the waist into two pieces that become narrower at the bottom, worn by men at very formal events

examples.en: The men all wore top hat and tails.

variants.html: tails

senses.definition: the side of a coin that does not have a picture of the head of a person on it, used as one choice when a coin is tossed to decide something

idioms.word: can’t make head nor/or tail of something

senses.definition: to be unable to understand something

examples.en: I couldn't make head nor tail of what he was saying.

senses.definition: to be very busy but in fact achieve very little
used to ask somebody which side of a coin they think will be facing upwards when it is tossed in order to decide something by chance

examples.en: The traffic was nose to tail for miles.

senses.definition: an unpleasant feature that comes at the end of a story, an event, etc. and makes it less good, successful, etc.
used to describe a situation in which the most important aspect is being influenced and controlled by somebody/something that is not as important

idioms.word: with your tail between your legs

senses.definition: feeling ashamed or unhappy because you have been defeated or punished
to follow somebody closely, especially in order to watch where they go and what they do

examples.en: A private detective had been tailing them for several weeks.

senses.definition: to cut the top and bottom parts off fruit and vegetables to prepare them to be cooked or eaten

examples.cf: take something for somebody to do something

senses.definition: to photograph somebody/something

a scene or part of a film that is filmed at one time without stopping the camera

senses.definition: to recognize the difference between one thing or person and another

examples.en: It was hard to tell the difference between the two versions.
Can you tell Tom from his twin brother?
Can you tell this copy from the original?
It's difficult to tell them apart.
The kittens look exactly alike—how can you tell which is which?
I couldn't tell who was meant to be the chairman.

senses.definition: to have an effect on somebody/something, especially a bad one

examples.en: The strain was beginning to tell on the rescue team.

senses.definition: with all people, etc. counted and included

examples.en: There are 52 people coming, all told.

senses.definition: used to say that you know or can guess what somebody is going to say, especially because it is typical of them

examples.en: Don't tell me you were late again!

senses.definition: to hear people talking about something

examples.en: I've often heard tell of such things.

senses.definition: used to tell somebody the true facts about a situation, especially when these are not known by other people

examples.en: If the truth be known, I was afraid to tell anyone.

senses.definition: used to say that something you have just said is not true or correct

examples.en: We first met in 2006, no, I tell a lie, it was 2007.

idioms.word: I tell you | I can tell you | I’m telling you

senses.definition: used to emphasize what you are saying, especially when it is surprising or difficult to believe

examples.en: It isn't cheap, I can tell you!
I'm telling you, that's exactly what she said.

senses.definition: used to introduce a suggestion

examples.en: I'll tell you what—let's stay in instead.

senses.definition: used when something bad has happened, to remind somebody that you warned them about it and they did not listen to you
a way of referring to somebody talking publicly, usually for money, about a past sexual relationship with somebody famous
used to say that somebody told you something but you do not want to say who it was

idioms.word: live, etc. to tell the tale

senses.definition: to survive a difficult or dangerous experience so that you can tell others what really happened
to give some information that is different from what you expect or have been told

examples.en: These drugs are widely believed to be effective medications. The data, however, tell a different story.

senses.definition: used to introduce a question

examples.en: Tell me, have you had lunch yet?

senses.definition: used to say that you understand what somebody is talking about and have had the same experience

examples.en: ‘I get so annoyed with Steve!’ ‘Tell me about it. He drives me crazy.’

senses.definition: used to tell somebody that you do not believe what they have said
to explain itself, without needing any further explanation or comment

examples.en: Her face told its own story.

senses.definition: to tell somebody about something that another person has done wrong

idioms.word: tell somebody/know a thing or two (about somebody/something)

senses.definition: to tell somebody/know some useful, interesting or surprising information about somebody/something

examples.en: After winning several Oscars, Nick Park can tell you a thing or two about making animated films.

variants.html: (North American English tell time)

senses.definition: to read the time from a clock, etc.

examples.en: She's only five—she hasn't learnt to tell the time yet.

idioms.word: tell somebody where to get off/where they can get off

senses.definition: to make it clear to somebody that you will no longer accept their bad behaviour

idioms.word: tell somebody where to put/stick something | tell somebody what they can do with something

senses.definition: to make it clear to somebody that you are angry and are rejecting what they are offering you
used to say that it is impossible to know what happened or will happen

examples.en: There's no telling how they'll react.

idioms.word: time (alone) will tell | only time will tell

senses.definition: used to say that you will have to wait for some time to find out the result of a situation

examples.en: Only time will tell if the treatment has been successful.

senses.definition: used when admitting something

examples.en: To tell the truth, I fell asleep in the middle of her talk.

idioms.word: you can never tell | you never can tell

senses.definition: you can never be sure, for example because things are not always what they appear to be
I completely agree with you

variants.html: (abbreviation temp)

senses.definition: the measurement in degrees of how hot or cold a thing or place is

examples.en: high/low temperatures
cold/warm temperatures
a drop/rise in temperature
The temperature has risen (by) five degrees.
Some places have had temperatures in the 40s (= over 40° centigrade).
Chemical reactions take place more slowly at low temperatures.
the water/air/surface temperature
Heat the oven to a temperature of 200°C (= degrees centigrade).
The climate is generally mild, and freezing temperatures are almost unknown.

senses.definition: the measurement of how hot somebody’s body is

examples.en: to take somebody’s temperature (= measure the temperature of somebody’s body using a special instrument)
Does he have a temperature (= is it higher than normal, because of illness)?
He's in bed with a temperature of 40°.
When your body temperature rises, your body tries to compensate.
She's running a temperature (= it is higher than normal).
They used ice packs to bring down her temperature.

senses.definition: to increase/decrease the amount of excitement, emotion, etc. in a situation

examples.en: His angry refusal to agree raised the temperature of the meeting.
The government tried to lower the political temperature by agreeing to some of the demands.

senses.definition: a building used for religious worship, especially in religions other than Christianity

examples.en: the Temple of Diana at Ephesus
a Buddhist/Hindu/Sikh temple
to go to temple (= to a service in a synagogue, where Jewish people worship)

senses.definition: each of the flat parts at the sides of the head, at the same level as the eyes and higher

examples.en: He had black hair, greying at the temples.
There was a throbbing in her temples.

senses.definition: in a way that lasts or is intended to last or be used only for a short time; in a way that is not permanent

examples.en: We regret this service is temporarily unavailable.
The company announced that it would be temporarily closing the factory because of the global downturn.

senses.definition: lasting or intended to last or be used only for a short time; not permanent

examples.en: to hire temporary workers
They had to move into temporary accommodation.
Volunteers built temporary shelters for the survivors.
temporary relief from pain
a temporary fix/measure/solution
More than half the staff are temporary.

senses.definition: to attract somebody or make somebody want to do or have something, even if they know it is wrong

examples.en: I was tempted by the dessert menu.
Don't tempt thieves by leaving valuables clearly visible.
He was tempted into a life of crime.
I was tempted to take the day off.

senses.definition: to persuade or try to persuade somebody to do something that you want them to do, for example by offering them something

examples.en: How can we tempt young people into engineering?
Nothing would tempt me to live here.

senses.definition: to do something too confidently in a way that might mean that your good luck will come to an end

examples.en: She felt it would be tempting fate to try the difficult climb a second time.
It would be tempting fate to say that we will definitely win the game.
There are only ten of these rare animals left.
ten of Sweden’s top financial experts
Twelve people were invited but only ten turned up.
Do you have change for ten dollars?
a ten-month contract
Look at page ten.
Ten and two is twelve.
Two tens are twenty.
I can't read your writing—is this meant to be a ten?
The bulbs are planted in sevens or tens (= groups of seven or ten).
We moved to America when I was ten (= ten years old).
Shall we meet at ten (= at ten o'clock), then?

senses.definition: used to say that somebody has guessed something correctly or done something very well

examples.en: Not brilliant, Robyn, but I'll give you ten out of ten for effort.

senses.definition: very probably

examples.en: Ten to one he'll be late.

variants.text: (North American English a dime a dozen)
variants.html: (North American English a dime a dozen)

senses.definition: very common and therefore not valuable

examples.en: Teachers of history are ten a penny.

senses.definition: a person who pays rent for the use of a room, building, land, etc. to the person who owns it

examples.en: They had evicted their tenants for non-payment of rent.
The decorating was done by a previous tenant.
tenant farmers (= ones who do not own their own farms)

senses.definition: to live or work in a place as a tenant

examples.en: a tenanted farm

senses.definition: to be likely to do something or to happen in a particular way because this is what often or usually happens

examples.en: Women tend to live longer than men.
People tend to be happier if they are in a long-term relationship.
When I'm tired, I tend to make mistakes.
It tends to get very cold here in the winter.

I tend to agree with many of the points you make.
I tend to focus on dance, but acting and singing are equally important to me.
Large class size will tend to increase the use of the lecture.

senses.definition: to take a particular direction or often have a particular quality

examples.en: His views tend towards the extreme.
Prices have tended downwards over recent years.

senses.definition: to care for somebody/something

examples.en: a shepherd tending his sheep
Doctors and nurses tended the injured.
well-tended gardens
Ambulance crews were tending to the injured.

senses.definition: to serve customers in a store, bar, etc.

examples.en: He had a job tending bar in San Francisco.

senses.definition: if somebody/something has a particular tendency, they are likely to behave or act in a particular way

examples.en: to display artistic tendencies
I have a tendency to talk too much when I'm nervous.
This material has a tendency to shrink when washed.

examples.cf: tendency for somebody/something to do something
examples.en: There is a tendency for this disease to run in families.
She has a strong natural tendency towards caution.

senses.definition: a new custom that is starting to develop

examples.en: There's a growing tendency for women to marry later.
Industry showed a tendency towards increasingly centralized administration.

senses.definition: a group within a larger political group, whose views are more extreme than those of the rest of the group

examples.en: a growing separatist tendency within the Anglo-Irish community

senses.definition: kind, gentle and loving

examples.en: tender words

senses.definition: easy to bite through and cut

examples.en: This meat is extremely tender.
Boil the beans until they are tender.
four large slices of tender chicken

senses.definition: painful when you touch it

examples.en: My leg is still very tender where I banged it.
The back of my neck feels very tender.

senses.definition: easily hurt or damaged

examples.en: tender young plants

idioms.word: at a tender age | at the tender age of…

senses.definition: used in connection with somebody who is still young and does not have much experience

examples.en: He left home at the tender age of 15.
She shouldn't be having to deal with problems like this at such a tender age.

senses.definition: a formal offer to supply goods or do work at a stated price

examples.en: Cleaning services have been put out to tender (= companies have been asked to make offers to supply these services).
a competitive tender
A local firm submitted the lowest tender.
The bus company is inviting tenders for a number of new buses.

senses.definition: a truck attached to a steam engine, carrying fuel and water
a small boat, used for carrying people or goods between a larger boat and land
to make a formal offer to supply goods or do work at a stated price

examples.en: Local firms were invited to tender for the building contract.
competitive tendering

senses.definition: to offer or give something to somebody

examples.en: He has tendered his resignation to the prime minister.

senses.definition: a game in which two or four players use rackets to hit a ball backwards and forwards across a net on a specially marked court

examples.en: to play tennis
a tennis player/court/ball
I met a friend for a quick game of tennis after work.
a tennis match/tournament
She is a popular figure on the international tennis circuit.
He retired from competitive tennis at the age of 34.

senses.definition: a situation in which people do not trust each other, or feel unfriendly towards each other, and that may cause them to attack each other

examples.en: There is mounting tension along the border.
international/racial/political tensions
Family tensions and conflicts may lead to violence.
The incident has further increased tension between the two countries.

senses.definition: a situation in which the fact that there are different needs or interests causes difficulties

examples.en: There is often a tension between the aims of the company and the wishes of the employees.

senses.definition: a feeling of worry and stress that makes it impossible to relax

examples.en: nervous tension
We laughed and that helped ease the tension.
Walking and swimming are excellent for releasing tension.
a tension headache

senses.definition: the feeling of fear and excitement that is created by a writer or a film director

examples.en: dramatic tension
As the movie progresses the tension builds.

senses.definition: the state of being stretched tight; the extent to which something is stretched tight

examples.en: muscular tension
Adjust the string tension of your tennis racket to suit your style of playing.
When knitting, try to keep the same tension throughout.
Massage can relieve tension in your shoulders and back.

senses.definition: to make a wire, sail, etc. tight and stretched
a shelter made of a large sheet of canvas, nylon, etc. that is supported by poles and ropes fixed to the ground, and is used especially for camping

examples.en: to put up/take down a tent
to pitch (= put up) a tent
Food will be served in the hospitality tent (= for example at an outdoor show).
Everyone was sleeping outside in tents.

senses.definition: the period of time when somebody holds an important job, especially a political one; the act of holding an important job

examples.en: his four-year tenure as president

senses.definition: the right to stay permanently in your job, especially as a teacher at a university

examples.en: It's still extremely difficult to get tenure.
She has been granted tenure at Leeds University.

senses.definition: the legal right to live in a house or use a piece of land

examples.en: When you rent a house here, you don’t have security of tenure.

senses.definition: a word or phrase used as the name of something, especially one connected with a particular type of language

examples.en: a technical/legal/generic term
a glossary of terms
a term of abuse
What is the meaning of the term ‘globalization’?
William Gibson coined the term (= invented the term) ‘cyberspace’ in 1984.
‘Old man’ is a slang term for ‘father’.
The term ‘Generation X’ refers to the people born in the 1950s and 1960s.
‘Register’ is the term commonly used to describe different levels of formality in language.

variants.html: (North American English also trimester)

senses.definition: (especially in the UK) one of the three periods in the year during which classes are held in schools, universities, etc.

examples.en: the spring/summer/autumn/fall term

It's nearly the end of term.
It's nearly the end of the term.

senses.definition: a period of time for which something lasts; a fixed or limited time

examples.en: during the president’s first term of/in office
a term as president/mayor/governor/prime minister
He was sentenced to a prison/jail term of 25 years for the offence.
She served a five-year term of imprisonment.
The contract was for a fixed term of five years.
to extend the term of a loan
His presidential term expires at the end of May.

senses.definition: the end of a particular period of time, especially one for which something is expected to last

examples.en: His life had reached its natural term.
This view of the economy is approaching its term (= it will soon be old-fashioned).
The pregnancy went to full term (= lasted the normal length of time).
Her baby was born at term.

senses.definition: each of the various parts in a series, an equation, etc.
used to describe what will happen a long, short, etc. time in the future

examples.en: Such a development seems unlikely, at least in the short term (= it will not happen for quite a long time).
In the longer term, children of depressed mothers are more likely to suffer from childhood depression.

senses.definition: to use a particular name or word to describe somebody/something

examples.en: At his age, he can hardly be termed young.
His research focuses on what he loosely terms ‘African ceremonies’.
Her condition would be more accurately termed as ‘chronic fatigue’.

senses.definition: a building or set of buildings at an airport where passengers arrive and leave

examples.en: A second terminal was opened last year.
Your flight leaves from Terminal 3.

senses.definition: a place, building or set of buildings where journeys by train, bus or boat begin or end

examples.en: a railway/bus/ferry terminal

senses.definition: a piece of equipment, usually consisting of a keyboard and a screen that joins the user to a central computer system

examples.en: Internet terminals have been installed at most libraries.

senses.definition: a point at which connections can be made in an electric circuit

examples.en: a positive/negative terminal

senses.definition: that cannot be cured and will lead to death, often slowly

examples.en: He has terminal lung cancer.
The illness is usually terminal.
She's suffering from terminal (= very great) boredom.

senses.definition: suffering from an illness that cannot be cured and will lead to death

examples.en: a terminal patient

senses.definition: certain to get worse and come to an end

examples.en: The industry is in terminal decline.

senses.definition: at the end of something

examples.en: a terminal branch of a tree
terminal examinations (= at the end of a course, etc.)

senses.definition: to end; to make something end

examples.en: Your contract of employment terminates in December.

to terminate a pregnancy (= to perform or have an abortion)

senses.definition: to end a journey

examples.en: This train terminates at London Victoria.

senses.definition: the conditions that people offer, demand or accept when they make an agreement, an arrangement or a contract

examples.en: peace terms

These are the terms and conditions of your employment.

senses.definition: conditions that you agree to when you buy, sell, or pay for something; a price or cost

examples.en: to buy something on easy terms (= paying for it over a long period)
My terms are £20 a lesson.

senses.definition: a way of expressing yourself or of saying something

examples.en: We wish to protest in the strongest possible terms (= to say we are very angry).
I'll try to explain in simple terms.
The letter was brief, and couched in very polite terms.
She spoke of you in glowing terms (= expressing her admiration of you).

idioms.word: be on good, friendly, bad, etc. terms (with somebody)

senses.definition: to have a good, friendly, etc. relationship with somebody

examples.en: I had no idea that you and he were on such intimate terms (= were such close friends).
He is still on excellent terms with his ex-wife.
I'm on first-name terms with my boss now (= we call each other by our first names).

idioms.word: be on speaking terms (with somebody) | be speaking (to somebody)

senses.definition: to be willing to be polite or friendly towards somebody, especially after an argument

examples.en: She's not been on speaking terms with her uncle for years.
Are they speaking to each other again yet?

senses.definition: to reach an agreement with somebody; to find a way of living or working together

examples.en: The enemy was eventually forced to come to terms.

senses.definition: to accept something unpleasant by learning to deal with it

examples.en: She is still coming to terms with her son's death.

senses.definition: a statement containing two words that contradict each other’s meaning

examples.en: A ‘nomad settlement’ is a contradiction in terms.
The idea is almost a contradiction in terms.

senses.definition: clearly and strongly

examples.en: I told him what I thought of him in no uncertain terms.

idioms.word: in terms of something | in… terms

senses.definition: used to show what aspect of a subject you are talking about or how you are thinking about it

examples.en: The job is great in terms of salary, but it has its disadvantages.
This title ranks alongside the Olympics in terms of importance.
What does this mean in terms of cost?

In terms of extra staff—how many will we need?

He's talking in terms of starting a completely new career.

senses.definition: having the same advantages and disadvantages as somebody else

examples.en: Can our industry compete on equal terms with its overseas rivals?

idioms.word: on your own terms | on somebody’s terms

senses.definition: according to the conditions that you or somebody else decides

examples.en: I'll only take the job on my own terms.
I'm not doing it on your terms.

senses.definition: used to refer to an area of land when you are mentioning its natural features, for example, if it is rough, flat, etc.

examples.en: difficult/rough/mountainous terrain
They walked for miles across steep and inhospitable terrain.

senses.definition: very unpleasant; making you feel very unhappy, upset or frightened

examples.en: a terrible experience
What terrible news!
I've just had a terrible thought.
It was a terrible thing to happen to someone so young.
That’s a terrible thing to say!
It smells terrible in here.
It must have been terrible to witness the accident.

senses.definition: causing great harm or injury; very serious

examples.en: a terrible accident
He had suffered terrible injuries.
I'll have to stay with her—she's in a terrible state.
The storm was terrible and caused a lot of damage.

senses.definition: unhappy or ill

examples.en: I feel terrible—I think I'll go to bed.
You look terrible, you'd better sit down.

senses.definition: of very bad quality; very bad

examples.en: a terrible meal
Your driving is terrible!
I have a terrible memory for names.
Cyclists claim that most city streets are in terrible condition.

senses.definition: used to show the great extent or degree of something bad

examples.en: a terrible mistake
to be in terrible pain

It was a terrible tragedy.
I had a terrible job (= it was very difficult) to persuade her to come.
You’ll be in terrible trouble if you’re late again.
Sometimes the pain is so terrible I can't sleep.

senses.definition: very

examples.en: I'm terribly sorry—did I hurt you?

I’m not terribly interested in politics.

senses.definition: very much; very badly

examples.en: I miss him terribly.
They suffered terribly when their son was killed.
The experiment went terribly wrong.
Would you mind terribly if I didn’t come today?

senses.definition: excellent; wonderful

examples.en: I feel absolutely terrific today!
She's doing a terrific job.
You look terrific in that dress.
He was really terrific when I was in trouble.
That’s terrific news!
So nobody’s coming. Terrific!

senses.definition: very large; very great

examples.en: I've got a terrific amount of work to do.
We drove along at a terrific speed.

senses.definition: to make somebody feel extremely frightened

examples.en: Flying terrifies her.
Stop it! You’re terrifying the children!
He terrified employees at the bank into handing over cash.

senses.definition: land that is under the control of a particular country or political leader

examples.en: enemy/disputed/foreign territory
occupied territories
They have refused to allow UN troops to be stationed in their territory.

senses.definition: an area that one person, group, animal, etc. considers as their own and defends against others who try to enter it

examples.en: Blackbirds will defend their territory against intruders.
She seems to regard that end of the office as her territory.
Each of these gangs has its own territory.

senses.definition: an area of activity, especially one that is familiar/unfamiliar or somebody's particular responsibility

examples.en: This type of work is uncharted territory for us.
Legal problems are Andy's territory (= he deals with them).

senses.definition: an area of a town, country, etc. that somebody has responsibility for in their work or another activity

examples.en: Our representatives cover a very large territory.

senses.definition: a particular type of land

examples.en: unexplored territory

variants.html: (also Territory)

senses.definition: a country or an area that is part of the US, Australia, Canada or India but is not a state or province

examples.en: Guam and American Samoa are US territories.

senses.definition: to be a normal and accepted part of a particular job, situation, etc.

examples.en: She has to work late most days, but in her kind of job that goes with the territory.

senses.definition: in a place that has no connection with either of the people or sides who are meeting and so does not give an advantage to either of them

examples.en: We decided to meet on neutral territory.

senses.definition: the use of violent action in order to achieve political aims or to force a government to act

examples.en: an act of terrorism
the fight against terrorism
The government has sworn to do everything in its power to combat terrorism.

senses.definition: a person who takes part in terrorism

examples.en: The terrorists are threatening to blow up the plane.
a terrorist attack/bomb/group

senses.definition: an examination of somebody’s knowledge or ability, consisting of questions for them to answer or activities for them to perform

examples.en: an IQ test
a test on irregular verbs
Students take standardized tests in English and maths.
to do a test
to pass/fail a test
a good mark in the test
a good score on the test

senses.definition: a medical examination to discover what is wrong with you or to check the condition of your health

examples.en: The hospital is doing some tests.
We'll need to perform a series of tests.
screening tests for cancer
Three athletes were sent home after failing drugs tests.
The pregnancy test was positive.
negative/positive test results

senses.definition: an experiment to discover whether or how well something works, or to find out more information about it

examples.en: the results of laboratory tests
to conduct a nuclear test
Tests have shown high levels of pollutants in the water.
I'll run a diagnostic test to determine why the server keeps crashing.

senses.definition: a situation or an event that shows how good, strong, etc. somebody/something is

examples.en: The local elections will be a good test of the government's popularity.
He saw their separation as a test of the strength of their love.

variants.html: Test

senses.definition: a cricket or rugby match played between the teams of two different countries, usually as part of a series of matches on a tour

examples.en: They played well in the first Test against South Africa.
He will be first choice for the opening test against the All Blacks.

senses.definition: to put somebody/something in a situation that will show what their or its true qualities are

examples.en: His theories have never really been put to the test.
The latest pay dispute has really put her management skills to the test.

senses.definition: to prove to be good, popular, etc. over a long period of time

examples.en: Whether this new technology will stand the test of time remains to be seen.

senses.definition: to teach students only what is necessary in order to pass a particular test, rather than help them develop a range of skills
to find out how much somebody knows, or what they can do by asking them questions or giving them activities to perform

examples.en: Students will be tested at the end of each module.
Children are tested on core subjects at age 11.
We test all students in English and maths.
Applicants' skills, ability and knowledge are tested before job offers are made.
We test your English before deciding which class to put you in.

senses.definition: to perform well/badly in a test of knowledge or ability

examples.en: students who tested well in reading
There are people who test well and people who don’t.

senses.definition: to examine the blood, a part of the body, etc. to find out what is wrong with a person, or to check the condition of their health

examples.en: to test somebody’s eyesight/hearing
The doctor tested him for hepatitis.

senses.definition: to produce a particular result in a medical test

examples.en: She tested negative for HIV.
Two athletes tested positive for steroids.

senses.definition: to use or try a machine, substance, idea, etc. to find out how well it works or to find out more information about it

examples.en: Test your brakes regularly.

Our beauty products are not tested on animals.
The chef uses his family to test out new ideas for the restaurant menu.
They opened a single store in Europe to test out the market.
The software has been tested for viruses.
The water is regularly tested for purity.
Researchers are now testing the hypothesis against available data.

senses.definition: (of a machine or product) to perform well/badly in a test of how well it works

examples.en: The ad had tested badly with consumers.

senses.definition: to be difficult and therefore need all your strength, ability, etc.

examples.en: The long climb tested our fitness and stamina.

senses.definition: to find out what the situation is before doing something or making a decision

variants.html: (North American English tried and true)

senses.definition: that you have used or relied on in the past successfully

examples.en: a tried and tested method for solving the problem

senses.definition: to make a statement that something happened or that something is true, especially as a witness in court

examples.en: She refused to testify against her husband.

‘I was approached by a man I did not recognize,’ she testified.

senses.definition: to say that you believe something is true because you have evidence of it

examples.en: Too many young people are unable to write or spell well, as employers will testify.

senses.definition: to express your belief in God publicly
a thing that shows that something else exists or is true

examples.en: This increase in exports bears testimony to the successes of industry.
The pyramids are an eloquent testimony to the ancient Egyptians' engineering skills.

senses.definition: a formal written or spoken statement saying what you know to be true, usually in court

examples.en: a sworn testimony

senses.definition: a popular US news magazine, published every week. It was started in 1923 by Henry Luce (1898-1967), the husband of Clare Booth Luce, and Briton Hadden (1898-1929). It created offices for its journalists around the world and has developed a particular style of writing which is sometimes called Timese. The magazine now has several different international versions. People consider it a great honour to have their picture on the cover of the magazine, and as a special feature every year it chooses a man or woman of the year.

variants.html: the town

senses.definition: the people who live in a particular town

examples.en: The whole town is talking about it.

senses.definition: a man who frequently goes to fashionable parties, clubs, theatres, etc.

to dispose of toxic waste

senses.definition: a level of debt or high-risk investment that causes very serious problems for a bank or other financial institution

senses.definition: an object for children to play with

senses.definition: an object that you have for fun or pleasure rather than for a serious purpose

senses.definition: made as a copy of a particular thing and used for playing with

senses.definition: of a very small type

senses.definition: to find or discover somebody/something by looking carefully for them/it

examples.en: She traced a line in the sand.

senses.definition: to follow the shape or outline of something

senses.definition: a line or pattern on paper or a screen that shows information that is found by a machine

senses.definition: a search to find out information about the identity of somebody/something, especially what number a phone call was made from

examples.en: The police ran a trace on the call.

senses.definition: one of the two long pieces of leather that fasten a carriage or cart to the horse that pulls it
to start to behave badly and refuse to accept any discipline or control

senses.definition: a rough path or road, usually one that has not been built but that has been made by people walking there

senses.definition: the soundtrack of a film or video

senses.definition: a long, thin, straight piece of metal, wood or plastic that a curtain hangs from and moves along

senses.definition: from or living in a poor area or part of town
close to catching or finding the person or thing that you have been running after or searching for

senses.definition: to leave a place, especially to go home

senses.definition: far away from other people, houses, etc.

examples.en: They live miles off the beaten track.

senses.definition: to suddenly make somebody stop by frightening or surprising them; to suddenly stop because something has frightened or surprised you

senses.definition: to put school students into groups according to their ability

examples.en: Don't track mud on my clean floor.

senses.definition: to stay at the same level for a period of time

senses.definition: to sell a lot of something very quickly
